qas.question: What has zinc replaced in pipe organs?
Zinc, copper and aluminum alloys have use in what part of machinery?
Zinc in the main metal used in making which american currency?
What is zinc coated with to influence the look of pennies?
What has zinc been replaced with in pipe organs?
What is zinc coated with to influence the look of dimes?
What is the only metal used in American currency?
What is the only metal used in pipe organs?

context: Other widely used alloys that contain <b6_0>zinc<b6_0/> include nickel silver, typewriter metal, soft and aluminium solder, and commercial bronze. <b7_0>Zinc<b7_0/> is also used in contemporary pipe organs as a substitute for the traditional <a0_0><b4_0>lead/tin alloy<b4_0/><a0_0/> in pipes. Alloys of 85–88% zinc, 4–10% copper, and 2–8% aluminium find limited use in certain types of <a1_0>machine bearings<a1_0/>. Zinc is the primary metal used in making American <a2_0>one cent coins<a2_0/> since 1982. The zinc core is coated with a <a3_0><b5_0>thin layer of copper<b5_0/><a3_0/> to give the impression of a copper coin. In 1994, 33,200 tonnes (36,600 short tons) of zinc were used to produce 13.6 billion pennies in the United States.
